pletion of this lesson, the student

ave the student repeat the words
Visual Cue: Hold something close to you saying “mine” and “
TPR Point to yourself and say my, mine and draw something close to you.
A child holding a teddy bear.
Yes, it is my teddy bear.
Visual cue: Hold a teddy bear and say: “mine,” then “it is mine.”
Hold the teddy bear out to the student saying: “It this teddy bear yours?”
Ask again: “Is this teddy bear yours?
They respond: “Yes, it is my teddy bear.
Have student repeat after you if they are unsure.
Visual cue: point toward a picture of a boy and say he
Read the sentence: “He plays outside,” modeling playing (running, throwing ball etc.)
Have the student repeat: “He plays outside” while underlining each word on the screen
picture of a boy holding a ball
Circle the boy on the screen and ask: “Is the ball his?”
Student responds: “Yes, the ball is his.”
Have the student repeat: “The ball is his,” while underlining each word in the sentence.
A person pointing toward a girl.
Have the student clap out the word she as they spell it out
Read: “She runs at school,” and underline each word in the sentence.
Visual cue: Show a picture of a girl running preferably in a PE class or in front of a school.
Have student repeat: “She runs at school.”
Say and spell hers: h-e-r-s: hers
Have the student write hers on the screen.
Circle the picture of the girl with the cat, asking: “Is the cat hers?”
The student responds: “Yes, the cat is hers.”
Images: A person pointing toward themselves, a boy holding a toy, a girl holding something
Text: Please match text: (mine, hers, his)
Reads the words as they draw the line from the picture to the appropriate word: “mine, hers, his”
Model drawing lines from the correct picture to the correct word, choose one of the words or write one of your own.
Have the student say each word as they draw the line.
If they have trouble correct them and help guide toward the correct answer.
A group of people standing together eating fruit
Say and spell we: w-e- we
Student claps as they spell the word: w-e
TPR: motion in a circle to indicate you and the student saying “we.”
Visual cue: Have some fruit, acting like you are giving some to the student saying: “We eat fruit.”
Underline each word in the sentence saying: “
A group of people standing next to a house.
Have student write the word on the screen while saying each letter out loud.
by motioning toward the student giving them fruit again saying:
Circle the picture of the house.
Student responds: “Yes, this is our house.”
A group of people standing together with one person pointing toward them
student clap as they spell they
Visual cue: draw stick figures of two people with a dog, point to them and say: “they”
Ask: “Do they have dogs?” Use TPR to indicate a question and bark like a dog.
Student responds: “Yes, they have a dog.”
Ask: “Do they have cats?” Using to TPR to indicate a question and meow like a cat.
Student responds: “No, they do not have cats.”
A couple or family with a car.
Have the student write the word
Circle the people and car saying: “Their car.”
Ask: “Is this their car?” Use TPR to indicate a question
Student responds: “Yes, this is their car.”
a person pointing toward themselves (I), a boy (he), a girl (she), a group of people (we), and a group of people with another person pointing at them (they)
Model drawing lines from the correct picture to the correct word, choose one of the words or write one of your own.
Have the student say each word as they draw the line.
If they have trouble correct them and help guide toward the correct answer.
Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide
Circle different groups of people, asking “Who is this?”
The student responds in various ways, since it is a big group of people there are not right and wrong answers.
Encourage as much output as possible.

udent to read all of the words with teacher support.
